name: Emerald Kids: Folk Tales & Mythology for Young Listeners
description: A kid-friendly playlist of animated folk tales and mythology videos inspired by stories referenced in The Emerald podcast. This playlist starts with joyful creation stories, Mother Earth celebrations, and nature myths before exploring tricksters, transformations, and life's deeper mysteries. Josh Schrei's podcast explores myth and story through an adult lens, but many of the tales he references have wonderful children's versions. Suitable for young viewers (ages 4-12).

items.name: The Myth of Hades and Persephone - TED-Ed

sections.Summary: The Greek myth of how Persephone, daughter of harvest goddess Demeter, was taken to the Underworld by Hades - and how her return each spring brings life back to the earth.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Referenced in The Emerald's exploration of the Eleusinian Mysteries and the death/rebirth cycle. The maiden who becomes Queen of the Dead represents initiatory death - 'the girl bleeds and then the girl is gone.'
sections.Lesson: Change is part of life's cycle. Endings can lead to new beginnings, just as winter leads to spring.

metadata.video_title: The myth of Hades and Persephone - Iseult Gillespie

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)

items.name: The Egyptian Book of the Dead - TED-Ed

sections.Summary: Discover what ancient Egyptians believed happened after death. Follow a soul through the underworld, past monsters and guardians, to the final weighing of the heart against the feather of truth.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Central to 'No One Here Gets Out Alive' - Josh explores the Pyramid Texts and Egyptian funerary traditions, describing death as 'the falcon flies' and the soul rising to join the stars.
sections.Lesson: Ancient peoples weren't afraid of death - they prepared for it as an important journey. What we do in life matters.

metadata.video_title: The Egyptian Book of the Dead: A guidebook for the underworld - Tejal Gala

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)
emerald_episode.note: Egyptian Pyramid Texts and death traditions

items.name: Prometheus and the Gift of Fire - Greek Myth

sections.Summary: The Titan Prometheus steals fire from the gods on Mount Olympus and gives it to humanity, knowing he will be punished forever for his gift.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald connects fire myths across cultures - Prometheus, Coyote, Raven, and Maui all bring essential gifts to humans, often at great personal cost.
sections.Lesson: Some gifts are worth any price. Heroes sometimes sacrifice themselves so others can thrive.

emerald_episode.title: Fire mythology episodes
emerald_episode.note: Prometheus as fire-bringer and cosmic rebel

items.name: Stone Soup - Animated Folk Tale

sections.Summary: The classic European folk tale about strangers who teach a village the magic of sharing. A hungry traveler convinces villagers to contribute ingredients to a 'magical' soup made from a stone.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Referenced in The Emerald episode 'Stone Soup: In Which I Argue Strongly in Favor of The Worship of Rocks' (July 24, 2019). Josh uses this story to explore sacred stones across cultures.
sections.Lesson: Sharing and cooperation can create something wonderful that no one person could make alone.

emerald_episode.title: Stone Soup: In Which I Argue Strongly in Favor of The Worship of Rocks

items.name: The Epic of Gilgamesh - TED-Ed

sections.Summary: The world's oldest known story! King Gilgamesh of Uruk goes on an epic quest for immortality after losing his best friend Enkidu. A 4,000-year-old tale from ancient Mesopotamia.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Referenced extensively in The Emerald episode 'No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)' - Josh explores Gilgamesh's anxious quest for immortality and how he misses the signs of true immortality along the way.
sections.Lesson: The search for eternal life teaches us to appreciate the present moment. True immortality might be found in how we live, not in how long.

metadata.video_title: The epic of Gilgamesh, the king who tried to conquer death - Soraya Field Fiorio

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)

items.name: Little Red Riding Hood - Classic Fairy Tale

sections.Summary: A girl in a red hood journeys through a dangerous forest to visit her grandmother, encountering a cunning wolf along the way.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald episode 'Awake in the Forest of Dangers and Wonders' explores how 'the forest in these stories is more than just setting - it is a character of its own, alive, awake, animate, both treacherous and beautiful.'
sections.Lesson: The forest represents the unknown - both dangerous and full of wonder. We must be wise but not afraid to explore.

emerald_episode.title: Awake in the Forest of Dangers and Wonders
emerald_episode.note: The animate, living forest in fairy tales

metadata.youtube_search: Many animated versions available - search 'Little Red Riding Hood animated fairy tale'

items.name: Hansel and Gretel - Brothers Grimm

sections.Summary: Two children are abandoned in a deep forest and must find their way home, encountering a witch's house made of sweets along the way.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Another 'forest story' from The Emerald's exploration - the forest as initiatory space where children must face dangers and discover their own courage.
sections.Lesson: Sometimes we must face our fears and trust in ourselves and each other to find our way home.

emerald_episode.title: Awake in the Forest of Dangers and Wonders
emerald_episode.note: The forest as place of initiation and transformation

items.name: What is Myth? - Crash Course Mythology

sections.Summary: An animated introduction to world mythology! Learn what myths are, why humans tell stories, and how these ancient tales help us understand the world.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald podcast is built on the premise that 'the imaginative, poetic, animate heart of human experience — elucidated by so many cultures over so many thousands of years — is missing in modern discourse.'
sections.Lesson: Stories help us make sense of the world. Every culture has myths that teach us about nature, ourselves, and each other.

metadata.video_title: What Is Myth? Crash Course World Mythology #1

items.name: Earth Mothers: How the World Was Made

sections.Summary: Discover how different cultures imagine Mother Earth! From Gaia in Greece to Pachamama in Peru, meet the great goddesses who gave birth to mountains, rivers, and all living things.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald episode 'For the Divine Mother of the Universe' honors 'the goddess as the animating power of the universe itself, felt in bodies, alive in trees and stones and living geography.'
sections.Lesson: Many cultures see the Earth as our mother who gives us everything we need. Taking care of the Earth is like taking care of family.

metadata.video_title: Earth Mothers and Rebellious Sons - Creation Part 3: Crash Course World Mythology #4

emerald_episode.title: For the Divine Mother of the Universe (Remixed and Reissued)
emerald_episode.note: The goddess as animating power of creation

items.name: Creation Stories from Around the World - Crash Course

sections.Summary: How did the world begin? Different cultures have amazing answers! Some say a cosmic egg hatched. Others say gods shaped us from clay. Still others say we emerged from water or darkness into light.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores how 'creation stories' are not just about the past - they shape how cultures understand their place in the universe and their relationship with nature.
sections.Lesson: There are many beautiful ways to imagine how our world began. Each story teaches something important about being human.

metadata.video_title: Social Orders and Creation Stories: Crash Course World Mythology #5

items.name: Why Do We Have Seasons? - Demeter's Gift

sections.Summary: Demeter is the Greek goddess of the harvest who makes the crops grow. When she's happy, the earth blooms with flowers and fruit. This is why we have beautiful spring and summer!
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores Demeter and Persephone as part of 'the great cycle' - not just a sad story, but a celebration of how death and life are connected in nature's rhythms.
sections.Lesson: The changing seasons are a gift! Each season has its own beauty and purpose in the cycle of life.

metadata.related_video: The Hades and Persephone TED-Ed video explains this further

items.name: Mythical Birds: Eagles, Ravens, and Hummingbirds

sections.Summary: Birds appear in myths from every culture! Eagles carry messages to the sky gods, ravens bring light to the world, hummingbirds represent joy, and roosters announce each new day.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald has an episode featuring 'mythologies of eagles, falcons, macaws, roosters, ravens, hummingbirds, hoopoes and more' that 'invites a whole lot of upward soaring.'
sections.Lesson: Birds connect us to the sky and remind us that we can rise above our problems. Their songs celebrate each new day!

emerald_episode.title: The Emerald's Bird Mythology Episode
emerald_episode.note: Eagles, falcons, macaws, roosters, ravens, hummingbirds, hoopoes

items.name: Celebrating the Seasons: Ancient Festivals

sections.Summary: People have always celebrated nature's rhythms with festivals! Spring festivals welcome new life, summer celebrations honor the sun, autumn gives thanks for the harvest, and winter festivals bring light to the darkest days.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores how ancient peoples 'lived in rhythm with the seasons' and created 'rituals and festivals that marked the great turning points of the year.'
sections.Lesson: Celebrating nature's cycles helps us feel connected to the earth and to each other. Every season has something special to celebrate!

metadata.examples: Solstice celebrations, harvest festivals, spring equinox, Diwali, Hanukkah, Christmas, etc.

items.name: Japanese Death Poems for Kids (Haiku)

sections.Summary: In Japan, poets wrote special poems called 'jisei' at the end of their lives. These tiny poems (often haiku) capture feelings about nature, life, and the mystery of existence.
sections.Emerald_Reference: 'No One Here Gets Out Alive' shares several Japanese death poems: 'Farewell. I pass as all things do. Dew on the grass.' And: 'Empty-handed, I entered the world. Barefoot, I leave it.'
sections.Lesson: Poetry helps us express big feelings in small words. Nature reminds us that everything changes - and that's okay.

example_poems: Dew on the grass / I pass as all things do / Farewell
Autumn moon / So bright, so full / Here, then gone

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)

metadata.activity: Try writing your own haiku about nature: 5 syllables, 7 syllables, 5 syllables

items.name: The Tree of Life - World Trees in Mythology

sections.Summary: Many cultures imagine a great World Tree that connects heaven, earth, and the underworld. The Norse have Yggdrasil, a giant ash tree. Other cultures have sacred fig trees, oaks, or ceibas.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Trees appear throughout The Emerald as symbols of life, connection, and the animate world. The 'Akashatri' in Egyptian texts means 'the body is a tree' from which the soul rises.
sections.Lesson: Trees are some of the oldest living things on Earth. They give us air to breathe, homes for animals, and shade to rest in.

items.name: The Sun and Moon: How Day and Night Were Made

sections.Summary: Every culture has stories about the sun and moon! Some say they're siblings who take turns watching over us. Others say they're lovers who can only meet during eclipses. All celebrate the gift of light!
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores how 'the sun rises and sets' as part of the great rhythms that ancient peoples celebrated - light and dark, day and night, waking and sleeping.
sections.Lesson: The sun gives us warmth and helps plants grow. The moon lights the night and moves the tides. Together they create the rhythm of our days.

items.name: Water Spirits and Ocean Friends

sections.Summary: Dive into the world of water mythology! Meet river spirits, ocean gods and goddesses, friendly dolphins, wise whales, and the magical creatures who live beneath the waves.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores how water is sacred in nearly every culture - from sacred rivers like the Ganges to oceanic goddesses like Yemanja. Water gives life and connects us all.
sections.Lesson: Water is precious and full of life. Rivers, lakes, and oceans are homes to countless creatures and have been honored by peoples everywhere.

items.name: Animal Helpers in Mythology

sections.Summary: In myths from around the world, animals are wise helpers and teachers! Bears teach courage, foxes teach cleverness, elephants teach memory, and bees teach the value of working together.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald celebrates the 'animate world' where 'everything in nature - animals, plants, stones, rivers - was considered alive, aware, and worthy of relationship.'
sections.Lesson: Animals have so much to teach us. Each creature has its own wisdom and special gifts.

metadata.traditions: Universal - animal wisdom across all cultures

items.name: Trickster Tales: Anansi the Spider

sections.Summary: Anansi is a clever spider from West African and Caribbean folklore who uses his wits to outsmart much larger animals. He's funny, tricky, and always has a plan!
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald episode 'Trickster Jumps Sides' explores trickster figures across cultures - from Coyote to Loki to Anansi. Tricksters 'bend rules, cross boundaries, and generally mess with established orders.'
sections.Lesson: Cleverness and wit can be more powerful than strength. But tricksters also teach us that breaking rules has consequences!

metadata.video_title: Anansi and the Pot of Beans - Animated African Folktale

emerald_episode.title: Trickster Jumps Sides: Disruption and the Anatomy of Culture

items.name: How Maui Slowed the Sun - Polynesian Myth

sections.Summary: The demigod Maui captures the sun with magical ropes to make the days longer so his mother has time to dry her cloth. A trickster hero tale from Polynesian tradition.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Maui is another trickster figure referenced in The Emerald's exploration of how cultures worldwide have similar trickster archetypes who bring gifts to humanity.
sections.Lesson: Sometimes we need to be brave and clever to solve problems that affect everyone.

metadata.video_title: How Maui Slowed the Sun - Polynesian Mythology

emerald_episode.title: Trickster Jumps Sides: Disruption and the Anatomy of Culture

items.name: The Story of Jumping Mouse - Native American Tale

sections.Summary: A brave little mouse leaves home to search for the Sacred Mountains. Along the way, he gives away his most precious gifts to help others - and is transformed into something magnificent.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Told in 'No One Here Gets Out Alive' - Josh describes how Jumping Mouse is 'picked up and devoured by an eagle' at his moment of transformation. His friend Frog shouts: 'Now you have a new name! Now they will call you Eagle.'
sections.Lesson: True transformation often requires giving away what we thought was most important. What looks like an ending can be a new beginning.

metadata.recommended_book: The Story of Jumping Mouse by John Steptoe (Caldecott Honor Book)

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)
emerald_episode.note: The transformation story of Jumping Mouse becoming Eagle

youtube_read_aloud.search_suggestion: Search YouTube for 'Story of Jumping Mouse read aloud John Steptoe'

items.name: Raven Steals the Light - Pacific Northwest

sections.Summary: In the beginning, the world was in darkness. A clever Raven tricks an old chief into releasing the sun, moon, and stars that were hidden away in boxes.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores fire and light bringer myths across cultures. Raven, like Prometheus and Coyote, is a trickster who brings essential gifts to humanity.
sections.Lesson: Light and knowledge are meant to be shared with everyone, not hoarded by the few.

emerald_episode.title: Trickster Jumps Sides: Disruption and the Anatomy of Culture

metadata.youtube_search: Search 'Raven steals the light animated' on YouTube

items.name: The Norse Myth of Thor's Hammer - TED-Ed

sections.Summary: How did Thor get his mighty hammer Mjolnir? The trickster god Loki makes a bet with the dwarves that leads to the creation of the most powerful weapon in all the Norse realms.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Loki is prominently featured in 'Trickster Jumps Sides' as an example of the sacred trickster who 'messes with established orders' but is 'indispensable' to cultural renewal.
sections.Lesson: Even troublemakers can accidentally create wonderful things. The world needs both order and chaos.

metadata.video_title: The Norse myth that inspired 'The Lord of the Rings' - Iseult Gillespie

emerald_episode.title: Trickster Jumps Sides: Disruption and the Anatomy of Culture

items.name: Turtle Island: The World on Turtle's Back

sections.Summary: In many Indigenous cultures, North America is called 'Turtle Island.' This beautiful creation story tells how Sky Woman fell from the heavens, and a giant turtle offered its back to create a home for all beings.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald explores how 'traditional cultures tend to be constructed around networks of support' including 'turtles and elephants and the great mother goddess herself — who is known as the support of everything that is.'
sections.Lesson: The world is supported by cooperation and kindness. Even the smallest creature can help create something wonderful.

emerald_episode.title: Carry That Weight: On Mythic Burdens and Cosmic Supports
emerald_episode.note: Turtles as weight-bearers in world mythology

metadata.youtube_search: Search 'Turtle Island creation story animated' on YouTube

items.name: The Tibetan Book of the Dead Explained (for older kids)

sections.Summary: A gentle introduction to how Tibetan Buddhists think about what happens after we die - colorful visions, peaceful and wrathful beings, and the journey of consciousness.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Central to 'No One Here Gets Out Alive' - Josh describes how Tibetan practitioners 'journeyed into liminal spaces' repeatedly in meditation, learning to navigate the in-between states.
sections.Lesson: Many cultures have beautiful ideas about what happens after death. Learning about them helps us appreciate life.

metadata.video_title: The Tibetan Book of the Dead (1994 Documentary)
metadata.note: Best for older children with parent guidance - beautifully made documentary narrated by Leonard Cohen

emerald_episode.title: No One Here Gets Out Alive (The Death Episode)
emerald_episode.note: Tibetan Bardo practices and death navigation

items.name: How Coyote Stole Fire - Native American

sections.Summary: In the time before humans had fire, Coyote sees people suffering in the cold. With the help of animal friends, he steals fire from the Fire Beings on the mountaintop.
sections.Emerald_Reference: Fire-stealing myths appear across cultures. The Emerald explores how 'in dozens of cultures, fire is brought to human beings by a trickster, and the gift of fire has consequences too.'
sections.Lesson: Working together, even small animals can accomplish great things. Sharing important gifts helps everyone.

emerald_episode.title: Trickster Jumps Sides: Disruption and the Anatomy of Culture
emerald_episode.note: Coyote as fire-bringer and culture hero

metadata.recommended_book: How Coyote Stole Fire (various retellings available)

items.name: The Rainbow Serpent - Australian Aboriginal Creation

sections.Summary: The Rainbow Serpent is one of the most important beings in Aboriginal Australian mythology. This magnificent creature shaped the mountains, rivers, and valleys as it moved across the land, bringing life and color to the world.
sections.Emerald_Reference: The Emerald's exploration of animate landscapes connects to indigenous worldviews where 'the goddess is alive in trees and stones and living geography.'
sections.Lesson: The natural world is alive with stories. Rivers, mountains, and rainbows all have their own sacred histories.

metadata.youtube_search: Search 'Rainbow Serpent story for kids' on YouTube
